title: Using radioactive drugs to see inside your body - Pedro Brugarolas

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of injecting FDG into a patient's arm during a PET scan?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the presence of cancer cells

options.label: B
options.text: To slow down brain function in dementia patients

options.label: C
options.text: To locate an infection in the body

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the amount of glucose in the body

multiple-choice.question: What type of particle accelerator is used to create PET tracers like FDG?

options.label: A
options.text: Linear accelerator

options.label: B
options.text: Cyclotron

options.label: C
options.text: Synchrotron

options.label: D
options.text: Collider

multiple-choice.question: What happens to oxygen-18 when a proton collides with it in the cyclotron?

options.label: A
options.text: It turns into oxygen-16

options.label: B
options.text: It turns into fluorine-18

options.label: C
options.text: It remains unchanged

options.label: D
options.text: It turns into carbon-14

multiple-choice.question: Why is it essential to use FDG quickly after its production?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has a long half-life

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is highly toxic

options.label: C
options.text: Because it decays quickly due to radioactive decay

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is expensive to produce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of a radiolabeled tracer in a PET scan?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the presence of cancer cells

options.label: B
options.text: To locate an infection in the body

options.label: C
options.text: To travel through the circulatory system and get taken up by its target

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the amount of glucose in the body

multiple-choice.question: What type of emission occurs when the isotopes used in PET decay?

options.label: A
options.text: Alpha emission

options.label: B
options.text: Beta emission

options.label: C
options.text: Positron emission

options.label: D
options.text: Gamma emission

multiple-choice.question: How do the paired radiation detectors in the PET scanner work?

options.label: A
options.text: They detect the positrons emitted by the tracer

options.label: B
options.text: They detect the electrons emitted by the tracer

options.label: C
options.text: They detect the high-energy photons produced by the collision of positrons and electrons

options.label: D
options.text: They detect the radiation emitted by the cyclotron

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the significant advantages of PET scans in cancer diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: They can detect the spread of cancer after it has been spotted with other types of imaging

options.label: B
options.text: They can detect the spread of cancer before it can be spotted with other types of imaging

options.label: C
options.text: They can only detect the presence of cancer cells

options.label: D
options.text: They can only locate an infection in the body

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate amount of radiation exposure from a single PET scan comparable to?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of radiation exposure from a single chest X-ray

options.label: B
options.text: The amount of radiation exposure from a single CT scan

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of radiation exposure from natural radioactive sources over two or three years

options.label: D
options.text: The amount of radiation exposure from cosmic radiation after a single transatlantic flight

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential risks associated with PET scans?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of allergic reactions to the tracer

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of ionizing radiation exposure

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of infection from the injection

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of kidney damage from the tracer

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The constant rate of falling raindrops

options.label: C
options.text: Pyramid

options.text: It increases

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: The wetness per second from rain from the top and the wetness per meter from rain from the side

options.label: A
options.text: Minimize the amount of water falling onto you from above

options.label: B
options.text: Maximize the amount of water falling onto you from above

options.label: C
options.text: Try to get wet from the side as much as possible

options.label: D
options.text: Take a detour to avoid the rain

options.label: A
options.text: It increases

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases

options.label: C
options.text: It remains constant

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes unpredictable

options.label: A
options.text: The faster the person, the more rain they hit

options.label: B
options.text: The slower the person, the more rain they hit

options.label: C
options.text: The speed of the person has no effect on the amount of rain they hit

options.label: D
options.text: The relationship is unpredictable

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the primary reason why running through the rain gets you wetter than standing still?

options.label: A
options.text: The increased amount of rain hitting you from the top

options.label: B
options.text: The increased amount of rain hitting you from the side

options.label: C
options.text: The decreased amount of rain hitting you from the top

options.label: D

options.text: Doubles in size every hour

options.label: C
options.text: Quadruples in size every hour

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: When the blob is sleeping and forming a flat triangle

options.label: C
options.text: When the blob is exposed to extreme temperatures

options.text: Acute triangle

options.text: 5 cuts

options.text: 10 cuts

options.label: B
options.text: Cutting a square into smaller squares

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: An acute and an obtuse angle are formed, or two right angles are formed

title: How tall can a tree grow? - Valentin Hammoudi

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of tree species on Earth?
Where do the tallest known trees in the world, the Californian sequoias, primarily grow?

options.label: A
options.text: The Amazon rainforest

options.label: B
options.text: The misty Sierra Nevada mountains

options.label: C
options.text: The Great Barrier Reef

options.label: D
options.text: The Grand Canyon

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why trees are unable to grow taller than a certain height?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of sunlight

options.label: B
options.text: Limited root system

options.label: C
options.text: Inability to circulate sap effectively due to gravity

options.label: D
options.text: Insufficient nutrients in the soil

multiple-choice.question: What type of sap carries sugars generated in leaves during photosynthesis throughout a tree?

options.label: A
options.text: Xylem sap

options.label: B
options.text: Phloem sap

options.label: C
options.text: Root sap

options.label: D
options.text: Leaf sap

multiple-choice.question: What is the process called when water from the phloem sap is absorbed into the xylem to correct the balance of particles?

options.label: A
options.text: Osmotic movement

options.label: B
options.text: Transpiration

options.label: C
options.text: Capillary action

options.label: D
options.text: Photosynthesis

multiple-choice.question: What are the three forces that help the xylem sap travel up the trunk of a tree?

options.label: A
options.text: Gravity, transpiration, and root pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Transpiration, capillary action, and root pressure

options.label: C
options.text: Photosynthesis, respiration, and transpiration

options.label: D
options.text: Osmosis, diffusion, and active transport

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the model that explains why trees have limited heights, even in perfect growing conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: The hydraulic limitation hypothesis

options.label: B
options.text: The tree growth model

options.label: C
options.text: The sap circulation theory

options.label: D
options.text: The gravity limitation hypothesis

multiple-choice.question: According to the hydraulic limitation hypothesis, what happens to trees as they grow taller and taller?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce more sap

options.label: B
options.text: They absorb more nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: The supply of vital fluids begins to dwindle

options.label: D
options.text: They undergo more photosynthesis

multiple-choice.question: Why do trees eventually stop growing taller, according to the hydraulic limitation hypothesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they run out of nutrients

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are unable to produce enough sap

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can no longer afford the lost water that evaporates during photosynthesis

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are too heavy for their roots to support

multiple-choice.question: What is the main factor that shapes the height of trees, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Sunlight

options.label: B
options.text: Nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: Water

options.label: D
options.text: Gravity

title: How to raise successful kids -- without over-parenting - Julie Lythcott-Haims

multiple-choice.question: What motivated the speaker to become a parenting expert?

options.label: A
options.text: They were interested in parenting and wanted to share their knowledge.

options.label: B
options.text: They were concerned about the impact of overparenting on children.

options.label: C
options.text: They wanted to help parents get their kids into top colleges.

options.label: D
options.text: They were a teacher and wanted to help parents with their children's education.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "checklisted childhood" the speaker refers to?

options.label: A
options.text: A childhood where kids are given a lot of freedom to make their own choices.

options.label: B
options.text: A childhood where kids are encouraged to explore their interests and passions.

options.label: C
options.text: A childhood where kids are constantly being directed and managed by their parents.

options.label: D
options.text: A childhood where kids are not allowed to participate in extracurricular activities.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result of overparenting on children?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident and self-assured.

options.label: B
options.text: They develop a sense of self-efficacy and are better equipped to handle challenges.

options.label: C
options.text: They become anxious, depressed, and lack a sense of self-worth.

options.label: D
options.text: They are more likely to get into top colleges.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "self-efficacy"?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to get good grades and scores.

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to make friends and be popular.

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to believe in oneself and one's abilities.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to follow rules and do what one is told.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Harvard Grant Study, what is a key predictor of professional success in life?

options.label: A
options.text: Getting good grades and scores.

options.label: B
options.text: Attending a top college.

options.label: C
options.text: Having done chores as a kid.

options.label: D
options.text: Being involved in extracurricular activities.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice to parents regarding their children's education?

options.label: A
options.text: To be more involved in their children's education and to push them to get good grades.

options.label: B
options.text: To give their children more freedom to make their own choices and to focus on their interests.

options.label: C
options.text: To be less obsessed with grades and scores and to focus on providing a nourishing environment.

options.label: D
options.text: To only focus on getting their children into top colleges.

multiple-choice.question: How can parents help their children develop a sense of self-worth?

options.label: A
options.text: By praising them constantly and giving them rewards for good behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: By providing unconditional love and support.

options.label: C
options.text: By pushing them to achieve high grades and scores.

options.label: D
options.text: By being overly critical and demanding.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the importance of attending a top college?

options.label: A
options.text: It is essential for success in life.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not as important as people think, and there are many other paths to success.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only important for certain careers.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not important at all.

multiple-choice.question: How can parents balance their desire to support their children with the need to give them independence?

options.label: A
options.text: By being constantly involved in their children's lives and making decisions for them.

options.label: B
options.text: By giving their children complete freedom to make their own choices.

options.label: C
options.text: By providing guidance and support while also giving their children space to make their own decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: By only focusing on their children's academic achievement.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to parents?

options.label: A
options.text: To be more involved in their children's education and to push them to achieve high grades and scores.

options.label: B
options.text: To give their children more freedom to make their own choices and to focus on their interests.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a nourishing environment, to strengthen their children through chores, and to love them unconditionally.

options.label: D
options.text: To only focus on getting their children into top colleges.

options.text: Depression

options.label: C
options.text: Bipolar disorder

options.label: D
options.text: Addiction

options.label: A
options.text: It's always difficult and requires special training

options.label: B
options.text: It's easy and can be enjoyable if done naturally

options.label: C
options.text: It's only possible with medication

options.label: D
options.text: It's not necessary

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It's a sign of weakness

options.label: C
options.text: It's only experienced by certain types of people

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on how to talk to someone with depression?

options.label: A
options.text: Use a sad voice and try to fix their problems

options.label: B
options.text: Talk naturally and avoid giving unsolicited advice

options.label: C
options.text: Avoid talking to them altogether

options.label: D
options.text: Try to cheer them up with jokes

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of giving someone with depression a sense of control?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps them feel more dependent on others

options.label: B
options.text: It allows them to make decisions about their own life

options.label: C
options.text: It's not important at all

options.label: D
options.text: It's only necessary in severe cases

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's suggestion for interacting with someone with depression?

options.label: A
options.text: Only talk about their depression

options.label: B
options.text: Avoid talking to them about anything

options.label: C
options.text: Interact with them about normal, everyday things

options.label: D
options.text: Try to distract them from their depression

multiple-choice.question: What is the guiding principle that the speaker suggests for talking to someone with depression?

options.label: A
options.text: Treat them like they're fragile and need special care

options.label: B
options.text: Talk to them like they belong and contribute exactly as they are

options.label: C
options.text: Try to fix their problems and offer solutions

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid talking to them altogether

title: How does the Rorschach inkblot test work? - Damion Searls

multiple-choice.question: Who invented the Rorschach Test in the early 20th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Sigmund Freud

options.label: B
options.text: Hermann Rorschach

options.label: C
options.text: Carl Jung

options.label: D
options.text: B.F. Skinner

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary focus of the Rorschach Test?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify specific mental illnesses

options.label: B
options.text: To analyze a person's general approach to perception

options.label: C
options.text: To measure a person's intelligence quotient (IQ)

options.label: D
options.text: To assess a person's creativity

multiple-choice.question: How did Hermann Rorschach develop his system to code people's responses to the inkblots?

options.label: A
options.text: By analyzing the content of their responses

options.label: B
options.text: By reducing the wide range of interpretations to a few manageable numbers

options.label: C
options.text: By categorizing responses based on their emotional tone

options.label: D
options.text: By comparing responses to a set of predetermined answers

multiple-choice.question: What did Rorschach's research find about people with the same personalities?

options.label: A
options.text: They gave identical responses to the inkblots

options.label: B
options.text: They took remarkably similar approaches to the test

options.label: C
options.text: They showed no consistent patterns in their responses

options.label: D
options.text: They had identical perceptual abilities

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the criticisms of the Rorschach Test in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: It was too time-consuming to administer

options.label: B
options.text: It was not effective in diagnosing mental illnesses

options.label: C
options.text: It was used in speculative ways without proper training or data

options.label: D
options.text: It was not widely available

options.label: A
options.text: The test was found to be invalid and unreliable

options.label: B
options.text: The test was found to be valid only for diagnosing certain mental illnesses

options.label: C
options.text: The test was found to yield valid results when administered properly

options.label: D
options.text: The test was found to be unnecessary in clinical settings

multiple-choice.question: How does the Rorschach Test differ from other personality tests?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a single right answer for each question

options.label: B
options.text: It is based on a person's verbal responses only

options.label: C
options.text: It uses a visual approach and lacks a single right answer

options.label: D
options.text: It is designed to measure a person's intelligence quotient (IQ)

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of using the Rorschach Test in clinical settings?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a quick and easy diagnosis of mental illnesses

options.label: B
options.text: It helps psychologists paint a more nuanced picture of how people see the world

options.label: C
options.text: It is a stand-alone key to the human mind

options.label: D
options.text: It is a reliable indicator of a person's creativity

multiple-choice.question: How did Hermann Rorschach's background in art influence his development of the Rorschach Test?

options.label: A
options.text: It led him to create more complex and intricate inkblots

options.label: B
options.text: It helped him understand the importance of visual perception in personality assessment

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on his development of the test

options.label: D
options.text: It led him to focus on verbal responses rather than visual ones

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the ways in which the Rorschach Test was misused in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: It was used to diagnose mental illnesses in remote communities

options.label: B
options.text: It was used to make prejudiced hiring decisions based on reductive decoding charts

options.label: C
options.text: It was used to assess a person's creativity

options.label: D
options.text: It was used to measure a person's intelligence quotient (IQ)

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: "Talking to the Enemy"

options.label: C
options.text: "The Art of Debate"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Power of Persuasion"

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Because it helps him to understand their perspectives and humanize them.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it makes him feel superior to them.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a sign of weakness.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: A model that codes colored light as brightness without color

multiple-choice.question: Why does the brain need models of itself?

options.label: A
options.text: To control focus effectively

options.label: B
options.text: To process visual information

options.label: C
options.text: To process auditory information

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore sensory input

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of neurons in the brain that are constantly interacting with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 billion

options.label: B
options.text: 10 billion

options.label: C
options.text: 86 billion

options.label: D
options.text: 100 billion

multiple-choice.question: What is a promising avenue for pinpointing the networks involved in creating the brain's self-model?

options.label: A
options.text: MRI studies

options.label: B
options.text: CT scans

options.label: C
options.text: EEG tests

options.label: D
options.text: PET scans

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of more extensive damage to the network involved in consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Hemispatial neglect

options.label: B
options.text: A vegetative state with no sign of consciousness

options.label: C
options.text: Increased consciousness

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased consciousness

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential outcome of approaching questions of consciousness with science?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in our understanding of human identity

options.label: B
options.text: No change in our understanding of human identity

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in our understanding of human identity

options.label: D
options.text: A complete understanding of human identity

title: Don't ask where I'm from, ask where I'm a local - Taiye Selasi

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's reaction when she was introduced as coming from Ghana and Nigeria during her book tour?

options.label: A
options.text: She felt proud to be associated with those countries.

options.label: B
options.text: She thought it was a lie because she didn't identify with those countries.

options.label: C
options.text: She was indifferent to the introduction.

options.label: D
options.text: She felt angry at the organizers of the book tour.

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker realize about countries when she learned about the concept of sovereign statehood?

options.label: A
options.text: That they were eternal and singular entities.

options.label: B
options.text: That they were invented and had a history.

options.label: C
options.text: That they were irrelevant in modern times.

options.label: D
options.text: That they were only defined by their geographical borders.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker propose as an alternative to asking "Where are you from?"

options.label: A
options.text: "What is your nationality?"

options.label: B
options.text: "Where do you live now?"

options.label: C
options.text: "Where are you a local?"

options.label: D
options.text: "What is your cultural identity?"

multiple-choice.question: What are the three "R's" that the speaker proposes to define a person's locality?

options.label: A
options.text: Rituals, Relationships, and Residency

options.label: B
options.text: Rituals, Relationships, and Restrictions

options.label: C
options.text: Rituals, Residency, and Roots

options.label: D
options.text: Relationships, Residency, and Routes

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with asking "Where are you from?"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too general and doesn't provide enough information.

options.label: B
options.text: It is too specific and doesn't allow for complexity.

options.label: C
options.text: It implies that a person's identity is defined by their nationality.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a power game that reinforces hierarchies between countries.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "multi-local"?

options.label: A
options.text: Having multiple nationalities.

options.label: B
options.text: Having multiple places of residence.

options.label: C
options.text: Having multiple layers of identity and experience.

options.label: D
options.text: Having multiple cultural affiliations.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker's friend Olu's experience illustrate the concept of multi-locality?

options.label: A
options.text: Olu has multiple nationalities and identifies with all of them.

options.label: B
options.text: Olu has lived in multiple countries and has a complex identity.

options.label: C
options.text: Olu has a single nationality but multiple cultural affiliations.

options.label: D
options.text: Olu's experience is not relevant to the concept of multi-locality.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument about the relationship between nationality and human experience?

options.label: A
options.text: Nationality is the most important aspect of human experience.

options.label: B
options.text: Nationality is irrelevant to human experience.

options.label: C
options.text: Nationality is just one aspect of human experience, and it is not the most important one.

options.label: D
options.text: Nationality determines human experience.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker's experience with her introductions during the book tour illustrate the problem with the language of nationality?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that nationality is not important.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that nationality is too general.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that nationality can be misleading and limiting.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that nationality is irrelevant.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's conclusion about the importance of locality in understanding human experience?

options.label: A
options.text: Locality is not important in understanding human experience.

options.label: B
options.text: Locality is only one aspect of human experience.

options.label: C
options.text: Locality is more important than nationality in understanding human experience.

options.label: D
options.text: Locality is the most important aspect of human experience.

title: Why should you read Shakespeare's "The Tempest"? - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What is the setting of Shakespeare's play, The Tempest?

options.label: A
options.text: A ship at sea

options.label: B
options.text: A desert island

options.label: C
options.text: A city in Italy

options.label: D
options.text: A forest in England

multiple-choice.question: Who is the exiled Duke of Milan and the ruler of the island in The Tempest?

options.label: A
options.text: Antonio

options.label: B
options.text: Prospero

options.label: C
options.text: Caliban

options.label: D
options.text: Ferdinand

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary motivation behind Prospero's actions in The Tempest?

options.label: A
options.text: To seek revenge against his brother Antonio

options.label: B
options.text: To find love for his daughter Miranda

options.label: C
options.text: To gain control over the island's resources

options.label: D
options.text: To explore the theme of colonialism

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between Prospero and Caliban in The Tempest?

options.label: A
options.text: Prospero is Caliban's friend and ally

options.label: B
options.text: Prospero is Caliban's master and ruler

options.label: C
options.text: Prospero and Caliban are equals and share power

options.label: D
options.text: Prospero and Caliban are enemies, but have no history together

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Ariel's character in The Tempest?

options.label: A
options.text: Ariel is a symbol of Prospero's power and control

options.label: B
options.text: Ariel is a representation of the island's natural resources

options.label: C
options.text: Ariel is a reminder of Prospero's debt and obligation to free him

options.label: D
options.text: Ariel is a minor character with no significant role

multiple-choice.question: How can The Tempest be interpreted in the context of colonialism?

options.label: A
options.text: The play celebrates the conquest of new lands and the subjugation of native peoples

options.label: B
options.text: The play explores the moral dilemmas and complexities of colonialism

options.label: C
options.text: The play ignores the theme of colonialism altogether

options.label: D
options.text: The play presents a simplistic and binary view of colonialism

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of Prospero's final lines in The Tempest?

options.label: A
options.text: They demonstrate his continued desire for power and control

options.label: B
options.text: They show his humility and recognition of the audience's power

options.label: C
options.text: They are a commentary on the theme of colonialism

options.label: D
options.text: They are a minor detail with no significant meaning

multiple-choice.question: How does Shakespeare's role as a playwright and entertainer relate to Prospero's character?

options.label: A
options.text: Shakespeare and Prospero are vastly different, with no similarities

options.label: B
options.text: Shakespeare and Prospero both wield power and control over their creations

options.label: C
options.text: Shakespeare and Prospero both surrender themselves to their audiences

options.label: D
options.text: Shakespeare and Prospero have no connection or parallel

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between Sycorax and the island in The Tempest?

options.label: A
options.text: Sycorax was a benevolent ruler who cared for the island and its inhabitants

options.label: B
options.text: Sycorax was a cruel and abusive ruler who exploited the island's resources

options.label: C
options.text: Sycorax had no connection to the island or its history

options.label: D
options.text: Sycorax was a minor character with no significant role

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall theme of The Tempest in relation to power and control?

options.label: A
options.text: The play celebrates the exercise of power and control over others

options.label: B
options.text: The play explores the complexities and moral dilemmas of power and control

options.label: C
options.text: The play ignores the theme of power and control altogether

options.label: D
options.text: The play presents a simplistic and binary view of power and control

title: The disarming case to act right now on climate change - Greta Thunberg

options.text: 10 years old

options.label: B
options.text: 8 years old

options.label: C
options.text: 12 years old

options.label: D
options.text: 15 years old

options.label: B
options.text: 10% per year

options.label: C
options.text: 15% per year

options.label: D
options.text: 20% per year

options.label: B
options.text: 200 species

options.label: C
options.text: 500 species

options.label: D
options.text: 1000 species

options.label: A
options.text: To avoid economic collapse

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure climate justice and allow poorer countries to develop

options.label: C
options.text: To mitigate the effects of air pollution

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent mass migration

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker believe that people are not taking action to reduce emissions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are evil and want to cause harm

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are unaware of the consequences of their actions

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too focused on economic growth

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not interested in the environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's response to the idea that they should be in school instead of protesting?

options.label: A
options.text: They agree that education is more important than activism

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that studying to become a climate scientist is the best way to solve the crisis

options.label: C
options.text: They argue that the climate crisis has already been solved and that action is needed now

options.label: D
options.text: They think that school is not relevant to the climate crisis

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker think is more important than hope in addressing the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Technology

options.label: B
options.text: Politics

options.label: C
options.text: Action

options.label: D
options.text: Education

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the current rate of oil consumption per day?

options.label: A
options.text: 50 million barrels

options.label: B
options.text: 100 million barrels

options.label: C
options.text: 200 million barrels

options.label: D
options.text: 500 million barrels

multiple-choice.question: Why does the speaker believe that the rules need to be changed to address the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the current rules are too strict

options.label: B
options.text: Because the current rules are not effective in reducing emissions

options.label: C
options.text: Because the current rules prioritize economic growth over the environment

options.label: D
options.text: Because the current rules are not based on science

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's conclusion about the need for change to address the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: That gradual change is sufficient

options.label: B
options.text: That change is needed, but it can wait

options.label: C
options.text: That everything needs to change, and it has to start today

options.label: D
options.text: That change is not possible

title: How do ocean currents work? - Jennifer Verduin

multiple-choice.question: In what year did a cargo ship carrying bath toys get caught in a storm, resulting in 28,000 rubber ducks and other toys being swept into the North Pacific?
What drives ocean currents?

options.label: A
options.text: Wind only

options.label: B
options.text: Tides only

options.label: C
options.text: Wind, tides, changes in water density, and the rotation of the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: The topography of the ocean floor and the shoreline only

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the ocean's water is controlled by surface currents?
What is the primary force behind surface currents in the open ocean?

options.label: A
options.text: Tides

options.label: B
options.text: Wind

options.label: C
options.text: Changes in water density

options.label: D
options.text: The rotation of the Earth

multiple-choice.question: What is the Coriolis Effect?

options.label: A
options.text: The way the Earth's rotation affects the wind patterns that give rise to surface currents

options.label: B
options.text: The way the wind patterns affect the Earth's rotation

options.label: C
options.text: The way the ocean currents affect the wind patterns

options.label: D
options.text: The way the wind patterns affect the ocean currents

multiple-choice.question: What drives deep ocean currents?

options.label: A
options.text: Wind

options.label: B
options.text: Tides

options.label: C
options.text: Changes in the density of seawater

options.label: D
options.text: The rotation of the Earth

multiple-choice.question: What is thermohaline circulation?

options.label: A
options.text: A horizontal current driven by wind

options.label: B
options.text: A vertical current driven by changes in the density of seawater

options.label: C
options.text: A surface current driven by tides

options.label: D
options.text: A deep ocean current driven by the rotation of the Earth

multiple-choice.question: What is the Global Conveyor Belt?

options.label: A
options.text: A surface current that carries warm water from the equator to the poles

options.label: B
options.text: A deep ocean current that carries cold water from the poles to the equator

options.label: C
options.text: A winding loop of thermohaline circulation and wind-driven surface currents

options.label: D
options.text: A current that carries nutrients from the depths of the ocean to the surface

multiple-choice.question: How long could it take a drop of water to make the full trip around the Global Conveyor Belt?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 years

options.label: B
options.text: 100 years

options.label: C
options.text: 1,000 years

options.label: D
options.text: 10,000 years

multiple-choice.question: What is happening to the Global Conveyor Belt due to rising sea temperatures?

options.label: A
options.text: It is speeding up

options.label: B
options.text: It is slowing down

options.label: C
options.text: It is staying the same

options.label: D
options.text: It is reversing direction
